How do I jump one word back in the terminal?
In most terminals, you can jump one word back using the key combination:

Alt + b (backward)

Or on Mac:
Option + ← (left arrow)

These are common Emacs-style keyboard shortcuts that work in bash and other shells. The equivalent to move forward one word is Alt + f or Option + → (right arrow).
In Kitty?
In the Kitty terminal, by default, you can jump one word back using:

Alt + Left Arrow 

or

Option + Left Arrow (on Mac)

You can also customize these key bindings in your kitty.conf file if you prefer different shortcuts.
Ho do I configure it in kitty.conf?
In your kitty.conf file (usually located at ~/.config/kitty/kitty.conf), you can configure word jumping shortcuts using the `map` command. Here's how:

```bash
# Jump one word back
map alt+left send_text all \x1b\x62  # Alt+Left jumps back one word
# or
map alt+b send_text all \x1b\x62     # Alt+B jumps back one word

# Jump one word forward (optional)
map alt+right send_text all \x1b\x66  # Alt+Right jumps forward one word
# or
map alt+f send_text all \x1b\x66      # Alt+F jumps forward one word
```

After making changes to kitty.conf, you'll need to restart Kitty or reload the config (typically Ctrl+Shift+F5) for the changes to take effect.

Note: The `\x1b\x62` and `\x1b\x66` are the escape sequences for word-back and word-forward respectively.
